Half-Life Deathmatch: Source is the Source engine port of the multiplayer portion of Half-Life.

At the time of this review, I only found one populated server, and it only had 4 other players. Obviously, this is old now, but I'm not sure why anyone would have wanted to play it over the other multiplayer Source or even GoldSrc mods. Well, the all time peak concurrent player count was 79, so I guess that speaks for itself. 

As with Half-Life: Source, it includes no new assets or textures, but adds new physics, lighting, and water effects. Unfortunately, it also includes new bugs!

Most people only have this in their library due to it being bundled with other Half-Life games, or the Valve Complete Pack.

Some maps are similar to quake style maps.  The graphic style is quite retro.  The player base is very small.  Some people will not like this game for various reasons.

Maybe only get this in the Half Life or Valve bundle and load it if you like PvP shooter games and the Half Life theme.  Check to see if you already have this game after buying the Half Life 2 bundle or games.  Alternate to this is the Half Life 2 Deathmatch.

his game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I didn't recommend Half-Life: Source and I definitely won't be recommending its multiplayer counterpart either. This game (which strangely came out two years after the Source port for the single player aspect) is like a prototype for Half-Life 2 Deathmatch. After the disaster of Half-Life: Source it's mind-boggling to think why Valve were so keen to release a multiplayer add-on. Despite the improvements of the Source engine over time - see Half-Life 2 Episode One, which came out around the same time - this game still feels wonky and a bit broken like the main game. The servers seem to all have bad latency no matter what, the rag-dolls are stiff and somewhat petrified-looking... and just to remind you that Valve don't give two turds about this game, you can't switch player model skins without tampering around in the developer console. Nice.  
So, will I recommend this game? Absolutely not. Even if you aren't a fan of Goldsource games, at least they're more heavily populated and (sort of) receive a little bit more acknowledgement from their creators. The original Half-Life is still a far superior experience. 
Half-Life Deathmatch: Source has no good reason to exist. It really is just another generic shooter that Valve threw together simply because they could. And, not that I hold it in much of a high regard, Half-Life 2 Deathmatch is the way to go for a "real" Half-Life multiplayer game.
It also doesn't have weapons that look as though they've been licked clean and polished for about forty years. So there's that, too.
There is no reason this game should be 3GB or a separate purchase to Half-Life: Source. Unless you want to use the models in Garry's Mod, buy the original Half-Life.

[i]Half-Life Deathmatch: Source[/i] provides some slight entertainment, but is overall a victim of modern enhancement.

This was probably a solid title upon its initial release, providing players with endless hours of fun, but now it is something completely different. The age on this title shows, whether you're considering the lack of modern incentives for deathmatch games or the almost completely dead player base, it just can't compete with most modern titles. The base gameplay from [i]Half-Life[/i] is present, which is stellar when applied to the game it was made for, but it isn't anything special in this format, at least nowadays. The fun to be had here wears thin, I'm not sure whether this is due to growing up with much more complex online multiplayer or it is a weak format for a deathmatch in general, but before I even complete a match, I'm often left bored and it just makes me want to play the original [i]Half-Life[/i] instead. Every time I have attempted to play the game, only one map is available to play on because really nobody else is on any other server, so you're strictly limited to that single arena, which I'm assuming is the most popular, but it isn't nearly good enough to warrant hours of gameplay. 

In my review of [i]Half-Life: Source[/i], I have elaborated on how useless the graphical upgrade has been as a replacement for the original game's textures, as it takes away a lot of the stylized charm and does little to improve what is already there. The game is completely playable in its original state, and already includes the original deathmatch servers in the game itself, therefore buying this bundle is useless even if you wanted to try it out, as [i]Half-Life[/i] already comes with the full package. Really, the problems I have with the [i]Source[/i] version of the original are ones I have with the [i]Source[/i] version of the deathmatch title, even more so due to its sheer uselessness. 

One would likely enjoy this deathmatch title over a decade ago, but nowadays, you'd be much better off with a modern title, or at least a classic that has substance and a living player base. [i]Half-Life Deathmatch: Source[/i] gets old fast, and is once again a more negative than positive experience out to take your money. Unless you hold some sort of nostalgia or are an avid fan of this title, do not waste your money on the [i]Source[/i] version of [i]Half-Life: Source[/i] and [i]Half-Life Deathmatch: Source[/i], just purchase the original and enjoy it in its originally intended way if you are going to play the deathmatch at all.

[h1] Retro Review[/h1] 
Okay this one is rather weird. Im not really sure why i own this one as you usually get this when buying the source port of the game. And since its based on the source port, im not surprised its completely dead.

[u] Gameplay[/u] 
You start off in every map with a pistol(except on modded servers) which in itself is already a huge problem. In other arena shooters you often start with some kind of competeable weapon, like a shotgun as an example. Here if you meet anyone who picked up any other weapon before you because they spawned closer to one or you joined a server midfight you instantly lose.

Then there is the weapons itself who are balanced in a singleplayer game in mind. This means some weapons are just completely devastating compared to others. There is even a meme on the community hub that you get automaticly good and easy kills by just picking up the grenade launcher(some even call it assault rifle). The movement isnt fast enough to be able to dodge rockets or grenades. This is why quake or any other games with similiar speed are working so well, explosions do pack a punch but are easier to dodge.

HL Deathmatch Source is also one of the most dead multiplayer games of valve, right next to ricochet and team deathmatch classic. There is a handful of servers that are completely empty. You might be lucky to find someone playing. Most play the original GoldSrc engine multiplayer.

[u]Aesthetics [/u] 
I think the map design looks good but arent made for this type of gameplay. There are some base maps that have barely any sideways to go, and feel rather liniar in a circle. Some even are outright straight designed which means dodging people makes it harder because often ways people will go is very predicable.

Due to the source port some graphical changes are made, but biggest difference is the really high quality water which totally looks out of place compared to the old player models and environment textures.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR [/u] 
This multiplayer game seems definetly charming with its huge arsenal of weapons but just fall flat in every aspect that makes an arena shooter good. The movement is too slow to dodge projectiles and explosions, maps are nice looking but badly designed from a gameplay standpoint and there are no players to find anymore. If you want to use the crazy Half Life weaponry on other players, rather try the original games multiplayer part instead.

I wanted to make this review short and sweet, but it's hard to stop writing, even when excluding facts that could potentially contaminate an exceptionally well thought-out gaming experience. There's just so much to say. Half-Life 2 is, simply put, the best single-player shooter ever released for the PC. It does so many things right in so many ways that it might be possible to write a thesis on the topic of Half-Life 2 compared to other single player shooters. What Valve has created is simply a masterpiece -- a work of art in the genre. Not only does it engage the mind with mysterious happenings, vagaries, and mostly intelligent dialogue, but also captures the senses with a superb visual style made possible by brilliant technology. And once the initial shock of it all wears off and it becomes possible to peel back the polished layers of sight and sound, there is an excellent shooter here. Half-Life 2 doesn't do anything particularly new; it doesn't really innovate in many ways. But what it does is set a new height for all other designers of first-person shooters to reach. It still isn't exactly perfect, but it's about as close as I've seen in my tenure here.

Before I really get into the review, you should know the background of how this game was reviewed. Valve did not want to send out copies of their game (for fairly obvious reasons) before it was released to the public. In order to play the game, I, and several of my colleagues throughout the industry, took a trip up to Seattle to visit Valve in order to have some private time with the title. I was given a little room to myself where I could close the door, turn off the lights, click my little red slippers, and pretend that I was sitting at home. It worked for the most part, largely because I was so engrossed with the game that when I came out of my trance I often had to take a moment to get my bearings. Obviously, Valve was happy to bring me into a controlled environment for ideal playing conditions.

[h1]New isn't always better[/h1]

[b]Half-Life Deathmatch: Source[/b] is a standalone port of the multiplayer mode in the original Half-Life that was developed on the GoldSource enginge. This port makes the game run on the newer engine that is simply just called Source. Unfortunately better engine doesn't always mean better game.

Half-Life Deathmatch: Source does everything you would expect. Better sound quality, better poerformance on newer computers and simply just faster to boot up. Unfortunately Half-Life Deathmatch: Source is a lazy port and doesn't really deserve to be played.

If you want a better experience on the Half-Life multiplayer I would suggest for you to pick up the original [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/70/HalfLife/]Half-Life[/url] for better experience. Sure, the engine might be clunky and outdated but trust me, you'll have better time playing it over this mess.

What is so different about Half-Life Deathmatch: Source compared to the original Half-Life multiplayer? Everything. Half-Life Deathmatch: Source feels nothing like the original. You get stuck on things; the movement feels extremely awkward. And that's the biggest problem. Even though the newer engine handles physics better than the old one it still manages to screw up the mechanics of the old multiplayer. Then comes the random crashes. And last but not least, oh no no this one right here is a huge problem, are that everyone in the game are bullet sponges. Sometimes it takes an eternity to kill just one enemy. Unless of course you've hoarded each and every exlposive weapon on the map. Then the multiplayer just becomes a domination spree for you.

So I don't know... How could I conclude this? Buy the original, don't even consider playing this one.

[b]Story:[/b] The story is Gordan Freeman has gone batsh*t crazy and fighting against himself. Apparently once upon a time you could change skins, and there was a community for this game. This is a completely unneeded port. It's less fun than the original. The community is dead. A few textures are improved, but most are still the same exact stretched old ones. If you didn't get this for free, and you buy it. There's something wrong with you.

After the release of Half-Life 2 and then the Orange Box, Valve had already remade and ported Counter-Strike, Half-Life, and Day of Defeat to the Source engine, and also made the unreleased "Team Fortress: Source". These remakes varied in quality, with Counter-Strike getting a full overhaul and Half-Life getting a simple port with barely any changes. It was around this time that Half-Life Deathmatch: Source was released. Like Half-Life: Source, it was a simple port from the GoldSrc engine that introduced very little changes.

In 2013, Valve introduced Steampipe, which would simpify downloading their games and not have them take up as much space. However, the update caused numerous bugs and glitches across all of their games, notably Half-Life: Source and -you guessed it- Half-Life Deathmatch: Source. As of writing, Valve has barely fixed any of these glitches.

Now, where do I begin?

Again, Half-Life Deathmatch: Source suffers from countless bugs and game breaking mechanics. Like Half-LIfe: Source, it shoves so many special effects into assets and maps created in[b] 1998	[/b]. The chrome effect that you could see on the revolver in the original Half-Life is slapped onto every weapon and every silver texture in the game. The lighting is okay by itself, but it's ruined by the overpowered bloom. I've seen better bloom in the Cinematic Mod for Half-Life 2! And there is so much more visualwise.

The hitboxes feel weird, and it seems that Valve fixed only the player hitbox so the game is somewhat fair. The MP5 grenade is a one hit kill and you'll bet that me and other players spam these like crazy. Just everything feels like it was stuck into the game, no adjustments, no tweaking,  left the way it is. 
Here is the final nail in the coffin for me: sometimes textures don't even show up on the map, and you'll be standing on an [i]invisible floor.	[/i]

This isn't Valve quality. This is the quality of a fan that just got into Source modding, and released this under Early Access as Pre-Alpha. But this game isn't the scams you'll find sitting under the Greenlight, this is a game released by Valve onto their own platform. And that's pretty disgraceful.

However, at it's core, it's still Half-Life Deathmatch, and it can be fun. So if you own the Orange Box and you're looking for something new, give this a try.

Otherwise, do not buy this game.

Summary: It may be more compatible with Windows 7/8/8.1 than HL1 normally is, but aside from compatibility and better lighting, there's not much to make this game worth your money.

First off, nothing has changed from HL1's multiplayer mode.  The maps may be running on Source, but there's still no props or anything-- it's still all just the map geometry.  More than that, you have to deal with the regular HL1 models without the HD pack, unless you feel the need to go through HL1 with Photoshop and do it yourself via modding (which will most likely not work on some servers).

Here's the real reason you want to stay away: 1) the GoldSrc HL1 has more players (source is pretty much empty, HL1 has a few players), and 2) this game is an EXTRA price.  That's right.  It's not like "oh, they just separated it because it's a big file" as Red Orchestra 2 and the CoD games do it.  No, you have to BUY the singleplayer for HL:Source (a broken mess) for $10, then HL Deathmatch Source is a standalone for you to slap down more money for.  Why not just buy HL1, with Deathmatch mode included?

Aside from what's above, what's advertised in HL Source isn't really that great.  The ragdoll physics are present, yes... however, they're bugged.  VERY bugged.  They lock up as soon as you die and you fall sideways in a stupid pose, whether you're posed to run in place on the ground, you're failing at parkour by getting your arm phased into a guardrail, or you're doing a handstand... sideways.  Other than ragdoll physics, the lighting looks better and the skybox is now 3D rather than a few jpg's of a New Mexico backdrop, but other than that this game has no real improvements.

Final verdict: It's a waste of money.  Just buy the old HL1, which will include this mode AND the singleplayer for $10 total.  It will also have HD models and the old death-animations rather than the failed ragdolls you see here.  It also has more players and better servers (both vanilla and modservers as opposed to a few vanilla).

It's not worth your cash, just add the original Half-Life (not HL Source) to your cart and move along.

To be short, it wasn't good idea at all. First, servers of original and remake aren't compitable, so it naturally splitted HL1 deathmatch community, in this case most stayed in original. Second, this Source remake as of right now is bugged. Not bugged enough to be unplayable, but just take look at popular map: Crossfire. The turrets there became unusuable, there is strange flying grate texture over lifts, it has double windows for some reason. Not pretty. 
So, stick to original Half-Life if you want multiplayer.
